so to delve in static analysis hopefully most people know what I'm talking about
and that's why they're here but you know just to level set it's an automated
method of inspecting you know source code on disk or source code as it's compiling or the exhaust of the
compilation process you know your bytecode or your binaries or whatever for flaws it's crucially not executing
the code as part of this analysis which is what distinguishes it from other automation techniques to look for
vulnerabilities things like dynamic analysis or runtime analysis so the static comes from it doesn't need to
execute the code and within static analysis there's five kind of primary
buckets of things trying to detect or kind of analysis techniques that we use to detect
problems the first is very simplistic we're just looking for various band
api's or kind of band assignments these are typically problems that like
grepping is a sufficient tool to find like hey it's stir copy present anywhere in my source code they're very
simplistic checks they're very easy to implement you don't even really need static analysis you can just use a
search feature of your IDE to find them but very quickly we get to kind of a
category that requires significantly more intelligence on the part of the tools so this is where it's not the use
of a specific API there's fundamentally a problem but how it is used the context
that it's used in that kind of differentiates between whether or not it's an issue so it's kind of a quick
example in older model view controller frameworks there's a persistent problem where if you remove a column from your
view but you don't also exclude it from your controller then you have a security
vulnerability if you exclude it from both places you're fine if you don't exclude it in either place
you're also fine so you're looking for specifically that context to determine
whether or not it's a vulnerability kind of within the contextual category there
are three specific analysis techniques that come up most frequently the first
is control flow analysis you're looking for all of the execution paths through
an application to see if there is a specific path in which your condition is met so you when we look at native code
for problems like memory corruption control flows the primary analysis technique we're looking for you we're
looking for you is there any path through all of the conditionals and branches where for example we freed
memory and then we're trying to use that memory again without doing an additional allocation so it's not to say that it
doesn't apply to more modern programming languages but it is most applicable
within the realm of unmanaged code for more modern languages we frequent
use a technique called data flow which is similar to control flow but we're rather looking for how a particular
value might flow through an application so a good example of this is for
symmetric encryption functions they have this concept of an initialization vector
which must be cryptographically randomly generated it can't be generated with just Rand or
some of the other garbage random number generators it has to be specifically cryptographically random and so what you
want to do is like once you find an instance of the symmetric function in AES or what have you look for its
initialization vector parameter and backtrack through the application to see if there's ever an instance where it is
initialized to something that isn't cryptographically random so you're looking at the flow of that data and
there's a specific subset of that most relevant to things like web applications
and most modern software is taint flow where you're very specifically looking
for untrusted data that is entering the application that then flows into a
method or function or assignment that is where it's not safe to use untrusted
data and you also want to check to make sure that in between the ingestion and the use there isn't a function that
turns it into something that's safe so these are things like cross-site scripting command injection deserialization attacks and that sort of
thing they're heavily reliant on being able to understand how taint enters the
application and flows down to an actual usage so these are kind of the broad
catch-all categories there are various detections that fall outside of these
but these will make up the majority of things that a good analysis solution needs to be capable of performing so
within static analysis you know we tend to gravitate to it as a solution for a number of strengths the first is that if
it understands how to analyze a language it hypothetically doesn't matter what
sort of application you're building in that one so if you're analyzing c-sharp it doesn't matter if you're building a web
application a windows form app a command line app blazer code because you're trying to script the Dom you so long as
it understands and is able to kind of parse and build a model of the c-sharp it hypothetically can cover all of those
now it still needs relevant checks to leverage that capability to be of use but that's you know it distinguishes
itself from things like dynamic analysis where you know maybe you have a web app scanner and that's great if you have a
web app but if you're writing a mobile app it's completely worthless so it's
able to span types of applications and this is important because there are a ton of application types where there
just doesn't exist good generalize dynamic or runtime analysis on the market so often this
makes static analysis really the only automation choice for those sorts of applications because it's not executing
the code as part of the analysis it typically scales much much better than either dynamic or runtime analysis so it
doesn't have the overhead and compute required to run often several permutations of the application in order
to perform the analysis which is both quicker and uses significantly less compute and crucially because it's not
executing the application and analyzing the behavior as the application runs there are many fewer variables involved
in the detection of results so if you run the same version of static analysis
on the same source code with the same rule set you should get the same results every time in you kind of the dynamic or
runtime space the order in which you run the you know various tests the initial
state of the machine all of these things will introduce variables that can
frequently cause you to get different results depending on those variables so
the reproducibility of the results is an important strength it's also much easier
to quantify how much of your application is analyzed you're the tool will typically tell you hey I've scanned this
many lines of code you come pair that two lines of code on disk and boom you've just quantified that you
know if you look at you the kind of other automation tools you have to invest quite a bit to instrument your
code in order to measure how much of the functionality was executed and even that is you're kind of a very fuzzy science
so you with other tooling it's really hard to tell hey have I covered all of my application whereas with static
analysis it's generally easy to answer that question now providing full
coverage of your application may be more involved most static analysis requires
you to compile compiled languages and as part of that compilation step things
like conditional compilation Flags within the source code can cause you to not analyze some of that source so just
because it's easy to quantify it doesn't mean it's necessarily trivial to get full coverage you know it still can
require a bit of work on your part but most importantly static analysis because
it's looking at the source code or you know some output that's representing representative of the source code that
it can map back to specific lines it can point us as developers to exactly the lines of code that caused it to think
something's a problem and focus our attention on fixing that which really
reduces the amount of Labor it takes to address any finding you know if you compare this to other tools or things
like penetration testing or whatever that's observing the behavior of the application after it's running there's
often quite a bit of investigation to backtrack to the actual offending lines of code that need to be changed so their
findings require significant labor to address in some cases whereas for static
analysis at the very least you know what to change pretty quickly but it's not
all rainbows and unicorns it's it's not a perfect technology even in abstraction
the first is pretty obvious it only has the context available of the code is
able to analyze so if you have several micro services and it's only their
behavior together where the problem arises you know one micro service is ingesting the data
